No—your employer violated the National Labor Relations Act. Discussing unions during non-work time (breaks, lunch, before/after shifts) is protected concerted activity. Your employer cannot prohibit these discussions, discipline you for them, or treat union talk differently than other personal conversations. If others can discuss sports or weekend plans on break, you can discuss unionization. File an unfair labor practice charge with the NLRB. Common employer tactics—prohibiting 'solicitation,' monitoring union discussions, disciplining organizers—often violate the NLRA. Don't be intimidated; your rights are clearly established.
My employer wants me to sign a non-disparagement agreement as part of a severance package. What should I know?

Non-disparagement clauses prevent you from saying negative things about the company. Consider: what specifically is prohibited (factual statements? opinions?), are there exceptions for legal proceedings or reporting to agencies, and is it mutual (does the company also agree not to disparage you)? Broad clauses can prevent you from reviewing the company online, discussing problems with former coworkers, or even being candid in job interviews. You may be able to negotiate narrower language. Some states limit non-disparagement in settlement agreements for harassment claims. Don't sign under pressure—you usually have time to review. Consider whether the severance is worth the restriction.
HR asked me to sign something saying I won't file a complaint with any government agency. Can they do that?

No. You cannot waive your right to file complaints with the EEOC, OSHA, SEC, or other government agencies. Any agreement purporting to prohibit such filings is unenforceable as to that provision. You can always file agency complaints regardless of what you signed. However, agreements can limit remedies—you might waive certain monetary relief while retaining the right to file. If an employer is asking you to sign away your right to contact government agencies, that's a red flag suggesting they're trying to cover something up. Refuse to sign or note the provision is unenforceable.
A coworker keeps telling me I should smile more. Is that harassment?

Repeated comments about smiling, particularly directed at women, can contribute to a hostile work environment based on sex. 'Smile more' is a gendered comment rarely directed at men. Document each instance—dates, context, witnesses. Tell them to stop: 'I'd prefer you not comment on my facial expressions.' If it continues after you've asked them to stop, report to HR. A single comment probably isn't actionable alone, but a pattern, especially if coupled with other gendered behavior, supports a harassment claim. The cumulative effect of many 'minor' incidents can create a hostile environment.
My boss keeps assigning me grunt work while giving better projects to others. Is that legal?

Legal unless it's based on a protected characteristic. If grunt work assignments correlate with race, sex, age, or another protected class—women get administrative tasks while men get high-profile projects, for example—that's discriminatory. Document the pattern: who gets what assignments, qualifications of people getting better work, any comments suggesting bias. If it started after protected activity (complaint, leave), it could be retaliation. Compare similarly qualified people across protected class lines. If there's no discriminatory pattern and your boss just doesn't like you, that's unfair but legal. Your options are discussing it directly, going to HR, or finding a better job.
I need medical leave but I'm still on probation. Do I have any protection?

FMLA only applies if you've worked 12 months and 1,250 hours. During probation, you likely don't qualify for FMLA. However, you may have other protections: ADA requires reasonable accommodations including leave for disability, regardless of tenure. Some states have family leave laws with lower eligibility thresholds. Pregnancy leave has some protections. Even without legal protection, many employers grant leave during probation if you communicate professionally. Document your request and the response. If you're denied leave and suspect it's because of disability or pregnancy, you may have an ADA or PDA claim even as a new employee.
I got a severance agreement that says I can't work for competitors for 2 years. Should I sign?

A 2-year non-compete is lengthy and can seriously limit your career options. Evaluate: how is 'competitor' defined (broad or narrow?), what geographic area, and what severance are you getting in return? Non-competes are increasingly unenforceable—check your state (California bans them entirely, others limit them). Even enforceable non-competes must be reasonable in scope. You can negotiate: shorter duration, narrower definition of competitors, geographic limits, or more severance in exchange. Don't sign immediately—you usually have time to review. An employment attorney can assess enforceability and help negotiate better terms. The leverage is: they want your signature; you don't have to give it.
My employer is retaliating against me by giving me glowing performance reviews.

That's an unusual claim—positive reviews are generally not adverse employment actions. Courts look at whether employer actions would dissuade a reasonable employee from engaging in protected activity. Positive reviews don't typically qualify. However, context matters: if the reviews are clearly inflated and setting you up for failure (giving you responsibilities you can't handle), or if good reviews create a paper trail contradicting a future pretextual termination, document that. If you believe something problematic is happening despite positive reviews, focus on concrete adverse actions: denied promotion, reduced pay, changed duties, ostracism. Those are actionable; the reviews themselves likely aren't.
Can my employer require me to get vaccinated?

Generally yes, with important exceptions. Private employers can require vaccinations as a condition of employment. However, they must accommodate: medical conditions that prevent vaccination (ADA), and sincerely held religious beliefs (Title VII). Accommodation might mean masking, testing, remote work, or reassignment—it doesn't automatically mean exemption without any alternative measures. If you need an accommodation, request it formally and engage in the interactive process. If denied without good reason, you may have a claim. Some states have laws limiting vaccine mandates, so check local rules. The process matters—employers must consider accommodations, not just say 'get vaccinated or be fired.'
My workplace bathroom is dirty and has no supplies. Is that a violation?

Yes. OSHA requires employers to provide adequate, sanitary toilet facilities with running water, soap, and toilet paper. Bathrooms must be kept in sanitary condition. Denial of bathroom access or inadequate facilities is a citable OSHA violation. Document the conditions (photos if possible), report to management, and if nothing changes, file an OSHA complaint. This is a basic workplace requirement. Additionally, some states have specific workplace sanitation standards that may be more stringent than federal OSHA. You're entitled to clean, functional, stocked bathrooms during your workday.
I'm being bullied by a coworker but HR won't do anything because it's not 'illegal' harassment. What are my options?

Workplace bullying that's not based on protected characteristics often falls outside legal protections, but you still have options. Check if your employer has anti-bullying policies—violations can result in discipline even if not illegal. Document everything and continue escalating: HR supervisor, your manager's manager, employee relations. If the bullying is affecting your health, a doctor's documentation can support accommodation requests or leave. If you develop a documented medical condition from the bullying, that might become an ADA issue. You can also consult an attorney to confirm there's truly no legal angle—sometimes harassment is based on protected characteristics that aren't obvious at first.
My manager asked if I'm planning to have kids in my interview. I got the job, but should I report it?

You can report it. Even though you weren't harmed by the question (you got the job), the question itself reveals potential pregnancy discrimination in hiring. Reporting creates a record in case the company discriminates against you or others later. It also alerts HR to a manager who's asking illegal questions and may help other candidates who weren't hired. That said, consider the dynamics—reporting may affect your relationship with this manager. You could report to HR confidentially or wait to see if discriminatory patterns emerge. Documenting the question and date protects you if you face discrimination later and need to show a pattern.
I overheard my manager say they won't promote anyone who takes FMLA. What should I do?

That statement indicates FMLA interference or discrimination, which is illegal. Document exactly what was said, when, and any witnesses. Report it to HR—this protects you if you need FMLA leave later and establishes the company knew about the discriminatory attitude. If you've taken FMLA and been denied promotion, you have a strong case. Even if you haven't yet, the statement creates potential liability the company should address. If HR doesn't act and you later need FMLA, the documented statement becomes evidence. Consider consulting an employment attorney if you've already experienced negative consequences for FMLA use.
My job posting advertised one salary but they offered me less. Is that legal?

In most states, job postings don't create binding contracts—employers can offer different terms. However, some states with pay transparency laws (Colorado, Washington, California, New York) require salary ranges in postings and may have enforcement mechanisms if actual offers don't align. Check your state. Even where legal, bait-and-switch tactics are a red flag about the employer. You can negotiate: 'The posting listed $X range. I expected an offer within that range. Can we discuss?' If they won't negotiate, consider whether this employer is worth working for. The practice may also indicate pay disparities worth examining—are they lowballing certain groups?
My employer demoted me while I was on medical leave. Is that legal?

Probably not. Under FMLA, you're entitled to return to the same or an equivalent position. Demoting you during leave violates that protection. Under ADA, adverse actions during disability-related leave can be discrimination. Document what position you held before leave versus what you returned to—duties, title, pay, reporting structure. If any are substantially worse, that's an adverse action. Request explanation in writing. If their reason doesn't hold up (restructuring that only affected you, claimed performance issues that don't match your record), that suggests pretext. File with the EEOC or DOL Wage and Hour Division if the employer won't restore your position.
I think I'm being set up to fail. What should I do?

Signs of being set up to fail: impossible deadlines, inadequate resources, contradictory instructions, exclusion from necessary information, sudden negative feedback after a history of good performance, documentation of minor issues. Document everything: save emails, note verbal instructions, create paper trails for resource requests and their denials. When given unrealistic assignments, respond in writing noting concerns: 'This timeline seems tight given X constraints. Can you clarify priorities?' CC yourself. Build external documentation (personal email, home computer) since you may lose access suddenly. Start job searching. If the setup correlates with protected activity or characteristics, consult an attorney before termination.
My company just got bought and the new owners are cutting all the older workers. Is that legal?

If layoffs disproportionately affect workers 40 and older, that's potential ADEA age discrimination. Look for patterns: are older workers being cut while younger, less experienced employees stay? Are they using criteria that correlate with age (tenure, salary level, being 'overqualified')? The fact of an acquisition doesn't immunize discrimination. Document who's being cut versus retained and their ages. If enough workers over 40 are affected, this could be a class action. Individual workers can also file EEOC complaints. Consult an employment attorney—age discrimination in post-acquisition layoffs is a recognized pattern. The new owners inherit legal obligations.
I disclosed a disability during the interactive accommodation process and now I'm being treated differently. Is that retaliation?

Changed treatment after disability disclosure can be both ADA discrimination and retaliation for requesting accommodation. The interactive process itself is protected—you can't be penalized for engaging in it. Document the timeline: when you disclosed, requested accommodation, and when treatment changed. Note specifics: exclusion from meetings, different assignments, negative comments, scrutiny you didn't face before. Compare to similarly situated employees without disabilities. If the employer claims legitimate reasons, assess whether they hold up—pretextual reasons are common. File with the EEOC. Employers are supposed to engage in good faith; punishing you for requesting what you're legally entitled to is unlawful.
